ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course helped me understand the process of archaeology and how it contributes to our understanding of ancient cultures. The framework was very theoretical and focused on reading about studies rather than conducting them ourselves.

I learned a lot about a subject that I previously had little exposure to. This course helped me to understand the basic nature of Anthropology from its origins and helped me to understand how data is gathered and interpreted.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One major weakness of this course was how the collection of assigned readings was somewhat unclear and disorganized. We ended up veering from the syllabus pretty substantially so I had to depend on checking emails for what the actual assignment would be. On the other hand, all of the content was super engaging!

The vast majority of the course is lecture-based with readings supporting the lecture. I learn well with this style of teaching so I found it to be a very strong way to retain the information. 

The only critique I could give is earlier knowledge of the details of the midterm/final, otherwise, it was an amazing course, and Dr. Weiss is a tremendous source of knowledge on the subject.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course as a history credit to someone who doesn't major in the social sciences as a fun, self-contained course. For more dedicated anthropology or archaeology students I think it would work as a good introductory course.

Absolutely. This course is an inquiry into the fundamental origins of civilization, with case studies from many different civilizations. Professor Weiss is passionate and has a wealth of experience. The scope and breadth of this course are unmatched, especially in the context of today's academic narrowness. I also greatly enjoyed the guest speakers who came to lecture about the civilizations in which they specialize.
Yes, I would recommend it and already have. The course really helps establish a frame of reference as to where/how civilization began.
